The work combined sound art, cassette tape loops, and print pieces exploring the intersection of artificial intelligence and human creativity.

Bling Kong was an 11-piece rock band from New York City: four cheerleaders, three drummers, two guitarists, one bassist, and a "video ninja."

We released *Do The Awesome* on Redder Records in 2005. SPIN Magazine wrote us up as "reform school cheerleaders backed by guys with an equal love for the Runaways, Electric Six, and penis humor."

The band was known for chaotic live shows and an aesthetic that blurred the line between rock concert and performance art.

## Links

- [Spotify](https://open.spotify.com/artist/4H4Dyiuny5OeVWLxbJ1H1l)
- [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bling_Kong)

Rhys Chatham. 200 electric guitars. Lincoln Center.

In August 2009, I performed as one of 200 guitarists in Rhys Chatham's *A Crimson Grail* at Lincoln Center's Damrosch Park, New York City.

The piece — an antiphonal work for 200 electric guitars, 16 electric basses, and percussion — was originally composed for 400 guitars and premiered at the Sacré-Cœur basilica in Paris in 2005. The Lincoln Center performance was a complete reworking commissioned for the outdoor summer festival.

An estimated 10,000 people attended. The performance was recorded and released on Nonesuch Records.

## Links

- [Nonesuch Records release](https://www.nonesuch.com/albums/crimson-grail)
- [Rhys Chatham's project page](https://rhyschatham.net/works-projects/a-crimson-grail-g200/)

Sound art installation. Concrete sounds, cassette loops, knife.

*Fiji Dance / Fiji Bus* was a sound art installation at the Inaugural exhibition, Ellipsis Gallery, Woolloomooloo.

The work speaks to the erosion of memory, employing recordings of my partner's voice while on holiday in Fiji. The tape is inexorably dragged across the upturned blade of a Stanley knife during the course of the show — slowly destroying itself.

The piece provided the ambient soundtrack for the opening night, and by the end of the exhibition, nothing remained.

**Exhibition:** Inaugural at Ellipsis Gallery, Sydney (2022)

Exhibition: Inaugural at Ellipsis Gallery, Sydney (2022)

Drone doom duo. Synthesizers, guitars, volume as instrument.

The Grey Men are a Sydney-based drone/doom duo exploring the outer limits of volume, texture, and endurance.

## Albums

- **The Shape of Noise to Come** (2024) — Inner Demons Records
- **Wealth** (2024)
- **Reverie** (2023)
- **Cascade** (2022)

Inspired by Earth, Sunn O))), and the raw physicality of sound, we use guitars, modular synthesizers, and field recordings to create music that's both harsh and transcendent.

[Listen on Bandcamp →](https://thegreymen.bandcamp.com)

Brooklyn indie rock. Temporary Residence Ltd.

Kilowatthours were an indie rock band originally from Louisville, Kentucky, later based in Brooklyn, New York. I joined in 2003.

The band released several albums on Temporary Residence Ltd and Springman Records, including a split CD with The Rum Diary.

The band later evolved into Up the Empire.

## Releases

- **Kilowatthours & The Rum Diary Split** (Springman Records, 2004)
- **Strain of Positive Thinking** (Temporary Residence Ltd, 2000)
- **Lessons in Time Management** (2000)
- **All Things Regarding** (1999)

## Links

- [Bandcamp](https://kilowatthours.bandcamp.com)
- [Discogs](https://www.discogs.com/artist/190406-Kilowatthours)

I performed as part of Glenn Branca's *Symphony No. 13 (Hallucination City)* for 100 electric guitars.

Branca originally conceived the symphony for 2,000 guitarists as part of the Paris millennium celebrations. When that didn't happen, he premiered the work on June 13, 2001, outdoors in front of the World Trade Center in New York. Subsequent performances took place in New Jersey, Los Angeles, St. Louis, and Rome.

The symphony represents the apex of Branca's explorations into massed guitars, alternate tunings, and the physical experience of volume as a compositional element.

## Links

- [Glenn Branca official site](https://glennbranca.com)
- [Flickr photos from performances](https://www.flickr.com/photos/noveller/albums/72057594060335896/)
